qas.question: around when did the great plains become productive for crop growing
what is the large underground layer of water in the great plains called?
what type of irrigation is used in the great plains?
When was the last ice age?
In what decade did center pivot irrigation get invented?
In what decade did aquafier depletion begin to outpace the ground's ability to recharge?
In what country was center pivot irrigation invented?

context: From <b3_0>the <a0_0><b4_0><b5_0>1950s<b5_0/><b4_0/><b3_0/><a0_0/> on, many areas of the Great Plains have become productive crop-growing areas because of extensive irrigation on large landholdings. The <b6_0>United States<b6_0/> is a major exporter of agricultural products. The southern portion of the Great Plains lies over the <a1_0>Ogallala Aquifer<a1_0/>, a huge underground layer of water-bearing strata dating from the last ice age. <a2_0>Center pivot irrigation<a2_0/> is used extensively in drier sections of the Great Plains, resulting in aquifer depletion at a rate that is greater than the ground's ability to recharge.
